headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Senate Woes Flag Wider Disease
summary: Scant middle ground in the Senate means few things are getting done there, but this unbending partisanship mirrors the political system's larger dysfunction.

headline: Fannie, Freddie Need More Short-Term Debt
summary: While one estimate puts Freddie's funding needs in the modest range of $10 billion to $20 billion, Fannie would need to raise about $60 billion.

headline: U.N. Rights Envoy Due in Myanmar
summary: The release of a leading dissident in Myanmar has intensified questions about whether the military regime will keep its promise to hold free and fair elections this year, and about what form the opposition will take.

headline: Tenure Battle Consumed Alabama Suspect
summary: The assistant professor of biology accused of fatally shooting three colleagues and wounding three others during a faculty meeting was described by her husband as demoralized over her failed battle to win tenure at the University of Alabama in Huntsville.

headline: Georgia Seeks Return of Luger's Body
summary: Officials in Georgia said they were working to return the body of luger Nodar Kumaritashvili to his mountain hometown for burial in a cemetery beside its small Georgian Orthodox church.

headline: Carolina Herrera's Elegant Style
summary: Ms. Herrera's tailored fit and understated elegance has won a loyal following among executives and celebrities.

headline: Clinton Warns on Iran's Military Power
summary: U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton accused Iran of drifting toward military dictatorship, intensifying criticism of the Islamic Republic as the Obama administration and its allies step up efforts on several fronts to enact fresh sanctions against Tehran.

headline: Dominican Probed in Missionary Case Admits Prior Charges
summary: Jorge Puello, a former legal adviser to some of the 10 American missionaries detained in Haiti, acknowledged in an interview that he is wanted in the U.S. on charges of smuggling people across borders.

headline: Kerry: India-Pakistan Talks Must Go On
summary: U.S. Senator John Kerry said he plans to meet with senior officials in both India and Pakistan, as he urged the two countries to not let a weekend bomb blast derail the resumption of diplomatic talks.

headline: Protests Shut Courts in Pakistan
summary: Pakistani lawyers boycotted courts n a protest against the government over its row with the country's top court on the appointment of judges, as rival political groups clashed in many cities.

headline: Corporate Watch
summary: Corporate Watch

headline: Luge Group Discussed Limiting Speeds
summary: The president of the International Luge Federation said Sunday night that the group's members had discussions to limit speeds at future luge tracks to 85 miles an hour before Friday's death of 21-year-old Nodar Kumaritashvili at the Whistler Sliding Centre.

headline: Agency Reviewing Toyota Crashes
summary: U.S. safety agency is reviewing nine additional fatal crashes involving Toyota vehicles, some going back as far as 2005. The claims haven't been substantiated.

headline: Marines Into Marjah
summary: A promising start to the Afghan campaign.

headline: Stephens: Major Hasan: The Counterlife
summary: The Fort Hood killer just missed becoming a civil-liberties martyr.

headline: Westpac Profit Surges 33%
summary: Westpac reported a 33% jump in first quarter cash earnings, underscoring the strength of Australia's big banks amid increasingly positive signs for the local economy.

headline: Clash of the Titans
summary: In "The Death of American Virtue," Ken Gormley gives an exhaustive account of Ken Starr's independent-counsel investigations and Bill Clinton's response to them. Jonathan Karl reviews.

headline: The Small Screen Also Hosts Big Opera Stage
summary: Regarding Heidi Waleson's "Opera: Divas on the Big Screen" (Leisure & Arts, Jan. 21): You can see Metropolitan Opera performances at a movie theater, if available in your hometown. But you can also watch Met movies on PBS. Ms. Waleson's comments on the big-screen experience is applicable also to the living-room experience.

headline: Take the Time to Keep Our Environment Safe
summary: In Philip K. Howard's "Washington vs. 'Common Sense' " (op-ed, Feb. 5) he says, "Cut the environmental review process to a year or two at most." Sir, we are all just passing through. Please allow people to do their job to assess the economic, social, and environmental impacts of projects without artificial time constraints.

headline: A Yawn for GOP Health Care Ideas
summary: In their "Ten GOP Health Ideas for Obama" (op-ed, Feb. 10), Newt Gingrich and John Goodman write that "Medicare is on an unsustainable course; the government has promised far more than it can deliver." One would think, then, that they would propose a way to reverse this unsustainable course.

headline: The Pioneer Spirit Versus Handouts
summary: North Dakotans pride themselves on their frontier mentality, work ethic and self-sufficiency. "Government-dependent" is a descriptor that would never cross our minds. The thought that our state vies for the top spot for federal handouts would, I hope, astound and embarrass the majority of our citizens.

headline: It Didn't Work Then, It Won't Work Now
summary: The editorial "Jimmy Carter Jobs Credit" (Feb. 10) which compares President Jimmy Carter's old Targeted Jobs Tax Credit program (TJTC) to Congress's current plan to provide a $5,000 tax credit per new hire is absolutely correct. President Obama's program to induce employers' to hire was tried in 1978 when the TJTC program was passed. It was mostly a failure, according to a 1994 Department of Labor report.

headline: More Bureaucracy Won't Prevent Future Meltdowns
summary: After reading Elizabeth Warren's "Wall Street's Race to the Bottom" (op-ed, Feb. 9), one would think Jaime Dimon was a bank robber on par with the late John Dillinger. Pardon my skepticism, but I doubt that every mortgage made by the banks over the last decade was "deceptive.

headline: Allen Barra: The Forgotten Miracle on Ice
summary: Twenty years before Lake Placid, a U.S. hockey team shocked the world.

headline: Coalition Troops Face Coordinated Attacks in Marjah
summary: U.S. Marines sent reinforcements to a beleaguered outpost where insurgent fighters were using women and children to carry weapons and shield their attacks on coalition forces in southern Afghanistan Monday.

headline: Toyota Repairs Progress
summary: Toyota has repaired about 500,000 of the 2.3 million vehicles recalled over a potentially sticky gas pedal, a senior executive said Monday, enabling many of the company's dealers to resume selling some of the cars sitting on their lots.

headline: Coalition Expects Taliban Resistance
summary: U.S. and Afghan commanders said their troops were engaged in several gun battles Monday in some sections of Marjah, the site of the first major test of a new U.S. strategy.

headline: Stocks in Europe Edge Up
summary: The FTSE 100 index rose 0.5% in London, while shares in Paris and Frankfurt gained 0.3% and 0.2%, respectively.

headline: Second Act
summary: Some past Winter Olympic greats on moving from sports to career.

headline: Gilles Moec: Spain Is No Greece
summary: Madrid's economic outlook is dire but fears of a national default are unwarranted.

headline: Yara to Acquire Terra for $4.1 Billion
summary: Norwegian fertilizer company Yara International agreed to acquire Terra Industries in a deal valued at $4.1 billion.

headline: European Bond Markets Steady
summary: European government bond markets held steady, with financial markets awaiting more details on an EU plan to resolve the Greek debt crisis.

headline: Gold Futures Climb
summary: Gold traded higher Monday as the euro's descent against the U.S. dollar paused and as traders awaited news from a meeting of euro-zone finance ministers about support for Greece.

headline: Ukraine Results Challenged
summary: Supporters of Ukrainian Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko said they will go to court Tuesday in an effort to nullify her defeat in the Feb. 7 presidential vote, though election officials have confirmed opposition leader Viktor Yanukovych as the winner.

headline: New York Fashion Week Slideshows
summary: A look at some of the biggest events and runway shows during Fashion Week

headline: U.K. Awards Gas-Storage License
summary: The British government tentatively approved the construction of a $942 million natural-gas storage facility aimed at correcting years of government and market failure to build enough back-up capacity to keep pace with demand and to fill unexpected supply disruptions.

headline: Eurostat to Look Into Greece Debt Swaps
summary: Europe's statistics office is seeking information from Greece concerning reports that the country used complicated currency swaps overseen by Wall Street investment banks to hide its mounting debt levels.

headline: Baltic States' Painful Progress
summary: As Greece resists European demands for wider austerity measures, the contrast with the Baltic states couldn't be starker.

headline: For BA, Regulatory Turbulence Eases
summary: Not only does it now look likely that British Airways and American Airlines will get antitrust immunity for their transatlantic alliance after all, but they seem destined do so at a much less onerous cost.

headline: Deadly Train Collision in Belgium
summary: Two commuter trains collided head-on in a Brussels suburb during rush hour Monday, killing at least 12 people, Belgian rail officials said.

headline: European Shares End Higher
summary: European shares closed modestly higher, as European leaders continued to grope toward a rescue package for debt-riddled Greece.

headline: BMW Oracle Wins America's Cup
summary: Larry Ellison's space-age trimaran BMW Oracle has won back the America's Cup for the United States by speeding across the Mediterranean to rout two-time defending champion Alinghi of Switzerland for a two-race sweep.

headline: Luger Who Died Was Terrified of Track
summary: The young Georgian luger who died in a horrific training accident hours before the opening of the Vancouver Winter Olympics on Friday told his father he was terrified of the track before doing the run that killed him.

headline: Japan 10-Year Yield Eases
summary: Japanese government-bond yields generally declined on concerns that China's monetary tightening could hurt Tokyo prices, in turn increasing demand for safe-have assets.

headline: Bharti Airtel Slumps in Weak Day for Asian Stocks
summary: Earnings disappointments in Australia hurt Asian stocks, as did deal talks between India's Bharti Airtel and Kuwait's Mobile Telecommunications.

headline: Oil Prices Edge Down
summary: Crude-oil futures slipped as debt concerns and weak fundamentals continued to weigh on sentiment, with Nymex crude at $74.01 a barrel in midday trade, off 13 cents.

headline: Weak Truck Demand Weighs on MAN
summary: The German truck maker and engineering company swung to a quarterly loss amid persistent poor demand for commercial vehicles and a $520.2 million write-down.

headline: The Flower, the Leaf and the Lobby: A Valentine's Tale
summary: It's odd that we celebrate love with perishable tokens.

headline: IMF Says Hungary Can Meet Target
summary: The International Monetary Fund believes Hungary can achieve its 2010 budget deficit target, but the country must strictly control its spending and use its budget reserves cautiously, the head of the fund's delegation to Hungary said.

headline: Diane von Furstenberg Layers It On
summary: Diane von Furstenberg's Fall 2010 runway show featured tailored jackets over flirty dresses, slouchy grandpa cardigans over silk dresses and lots of throw-it-on comfort.

headline: American, British Airways Alliance Approved
summary: The U.S. Department of Transportation approved an antitrust waiver that would allow American Airlines and British Airways to cooperate on trans-Atlantic routes.

headline: Virgin Wants Tougher Demands for Rivals' Alliance
summary: Virgin Atlantic called on the European Commission to force British Airways and American Airlines to give up far more than U.S. regulators have demanded in return for being allowed to expand their trans-Atlantic alliance.

headline: Why We Need Capital Security
summary: Strong demand has kept India's economy humming, now we need to bolster the foundations of capital formation, says Madhabi Puri-Buch, CEO of ICICI Securities.

headline: Mahindra: Loosen Limits on Defense Investment in India
summary: Anand Mahindra, vice chairman of Mahindra Group, urged the Indian government to increase its limit on foreign equity investment in defense companies to 49% so that domestic suppliers can get access to sensitive technologies from abroad.

headline: PVR: Pact to Acquire DT Cinemas Terminated
summary: Indian multiplex chain operator PVR said its agreement to acquire DT Cinemas from parent DLF Group has been terminated.

headline: Van Nistelrooy Gives Hamburg Spark
summary: The oft-injured Dutch forward shows his mental prowess after a free transfer from Real Madrid.

headline: Tata Motors Names Carl-Peter Forster Group CEO
summary: Tata Motors said it has appointed Carl-Peter Forster as group chief executive of the company.

headline: Canada's No-Gold Legacy Finally Ends
summary: Canadian Alexandre Bilodeau ended his country's 34-year reign as the only Olympic host never to have won a gold medal on its own soil.

headline: BAE to Book $927.7 Million Write-Down
summary: The U.K. defense giant said it will book a $927.7 million write-down in its 2009 accounts after it failed to win a follow-on contract for producing cargo trucks for the U.S. Army.

headline: SAIL: India Steel Prices May Rise
summary: India's steel prices could rise in the next fiscal year if global suppliers increase prices for raw materials, such as coking coal and iron ore, under annual supply agreements, the chairman of India's largest steelmaker said.

headline: India Official: El Nino Threat to Monsoon Fades
summary: The threat from El Nino, which contributed to the worst monsoon rains in India in nearly four decades last year, has subsided and the annual rains are expected to be normal this year, a senior weather official said.

headline: Ashok Leyland in Initial Pact With Paramount Group
summary: Ashok Leyland has entered into an initial pact with South Africa's Paramount Group to make mine protected vehicles in India. The mine protected vehicles will be based on Ashok Leyland's stallion platform, the company said.

headline: The Year of the Tiger
summary: Lunar New Year kicked off on Sunday, ushering in the Year of the Tiger. Take a look as millions travel across China to be with their family and friends for the longest and most important holiday on the Chinese calendar.

headline: BAE Expects to Start India Trial for Howitzer By Early March
summary: BAE Systems expects to start trials in India for its FH77 B05 towed howitzer by early March for a potential contract to sell 400 units to the Indian Army, a senior India executive said.

headline: AWB Settles Iraq Suit
summary: The agribusiness company will pay $35 million to resolve the last legal action it faces as a result of kickbacks to the regime of Saddam Hussein.

headline: Dubai World Weighs Debt Deal
summary: Dubai World may offer creditors 60% of the money they're owed backed by the sheikdom's government as part of a deal to reschedule $22 billion of debt.

headline: Cheney Attacks Obama on Security
summary: Dick Cheney renewed his attack on the Obama administration's national security policy, suggesting it was failing to prepare for another major terrorist assault.

headline: Indian Shares End Lower
summary: Indian shares ended lower Monday with Bharti Airtel plunging 9.2% as investors worried that the company may pay too much for its proposed purchase of the Africa assets of Kuwait's Mobile Telecommunications, or Zain.

headline: A New Turn for Alfa Romeo
summary: As Fiat prepares to unveil a new Alfa Romeo model, analysts said the Italian auto maker's best shot at making the sputtering sports-car brand profitable is to drop its premium status and position it closer to the masses.

headline: TUI's Net Loss Narrows
summary: The German tourism and shipping company said its fiscal first-quarter net loss narrowed on reduced administrative expenses and improvements in taxes.

headline: China Indicts Ex-Gome Chairman
summary: Huang Guangyu, once China's richest man, has been formally indicted on charges of insider trading, illegal business dealings and bribery.

headline: H&M Sales Beat Forecasts
summary: Fashion retailer Hennes & Mauritz reported a better-than-expected gain in same-store sales in January, marking the second consecutive monthly increase in sales.

headline: India Inflation Up 8.56% in January
summary: India's wholesale inflation accelerated to 8.56% in January from 7.31% in December, the government said.

headline: EU Leaders Meet to Avoid Greek Crisis
summary: After EU leaders broadly pledged to support Greece, the bloc's finance ministers are expected to hash out a more detailed contingency plan to ease the country's debt crisis.

headline: Olympic Photos: Alpine Skiing Still Hampered by Rain
summary: Women's skiers can't get in training runs; France's Jay wins gold in men's biathlon;  men's lugers and women's speedskaters chase medals; U.S. women's hockey routs China in preliminary-round opener; and more from Vancouver.

headline: ONGC May Invest Up to $30 Billion on Overseas Assets
summary: Oil & Natural Gas Corp., India's national flagship oil company, may invest between $25 billion and $30 billion over the next decade to buy and develop oil and gas assets overseas.

headline: Tata Motors Global Sales Surge 93%
summary: Tata Motors said its global automobile sales in January soared 93% to 85,714 units, helped by premium brands Jaguar and Land Rover.

headline: Corbett Warns of Capacity Constraints in Australia
summary: The greatest danger Australia's economy faces is a finite amount of spare capacity, one of the country's business leaders, Roger Corbett, said in an interview.

headline: Stone India, Sumitomo Electric to Form Joint Venture
summary: Stone India said it has signed a pact with Japan's Sumitomo Electric Industries to form a joint venture to make air springs for locomotives in India.

headline: Kearney Wins First U.S. Gold
summary: American moguls skier Hannah Kearney upset the defending Olympic champion, Canadian Jennifer Heil, to win the first U.S. gold medal of the 2010 Olympics.

headline: Toyota Plans to Boost Testing
summary: The auto maker is considering ways to bolster procedures for checking the quality and reliability of cars, and to do more to publicize incremental changes to cars on the market.

headline: German Economic Expectations Deteriorate
summary: German economic expectations deteriorated in February, indicating the economic recovery isn't gaining any significant momentum.

headline: Software Directs Mobile Industry
summary: The success of Apple and Google in the mobile industry has companies that traditionally haven't created software, like phone makers and network operators, trying to catch up.

headline: Counterfeit Drugs Roil Middle East
summary: A recent seizure of counterfeit drugs and the shutdown of the ring that provided them shows how Syria is stepping up its response to a problem that remains widespread.

headline: Nokia, Intel Unveil Operating System
summary: Handset maker Nokia and chip maker Intel said they are launching a mobile operating system which can run on a number of electronic devices including smart phones, laptops and TV sets.

headline: Mobile Operators to Build Apps Platform
summary: Twenty-four mobile operators formed an alliance to build an open platform to deliver applications to all mobile phone users, in an attempt to emulate the runaway success of Apple's App Store.

headline: Herrera Sees Signs of Life in Luxury
summary: Carolina Herrera has walked a fine line during the downturn, trying to cater to frugal consumers without damaging quality or image.

headline: The Accidental Terrorist
summary: Bollywood's latest blockbuster, 'My Name is Khan,' caricatures America's treatment of Muslims.

headline: The U.S. Goes Wobbly on Russia
summary: Iran's dictators feel secure too, writes Garry Kasparov.

headline: Brooklyn Decker's Cover Story
summary: Sports Illustrated's swimsuit issue star would just as soon talk hoops, football and tennis.

headline: Why Are You Lactose-Intolerant?
summary: Scientists turn to DNA in an attempt to answer why adults develop trouble digesting milk but can eat ice cream.

headline: RBS Sells Some Sempra Assets
summary: RBS said that J.P. Morgan Chase had agreed to buy parts of RBS Sempra Commodities, the energy-trading business owned by RBS and Sempra Energy, for $1.7 billion.

headline: China's Home-Team Edge on Property
summary: Foreign investors sit on the sidelines, weighing their next move, as local rivals attract investment and move through the Chinese real-estate industry with more ease.

headline: Taliban Resist Afghan Offensive
summary: U.S. and Afghan commanders braced for stiffer Taliban resistance as a major offensive into the southern Afghan town of Marjah continued.

headline: A Crush of 3-D Movies
summary: Hollywood is releasing a crush of 3-D movies this year in the wake of "Avatar." Costly productions could wind up cannibalizing each other as they jostle for limited movie screen.

headline: Why Some Foods Are Riskier Today
summary: A growing number of Americans have been sickened by foodborne illnessâ€”in many cases from food they never considered risky.

headline: Marine Walks Away From Shot to Head
summary: It is hard to know whether Monday was a very bad day or a very good day for Lance Cpl. Andrew Koenig in Afghanistan. On the one hand, he was shot in the head. On the other, the bullet bounced off him.

headline: Suspects Named in Hamas Killing
summary: Dubai police identified 11 suspects, all allegedly holding European passports, as wanted for the murder last month of a senior Hamas leader, and described a carefully choreographed assassination plot.

headline: Snapshots on Startups
summary: Eric Bellman of the WSJ reports from the Tech4Society conference on innovation and entrepreneurship in Hyderabad.

headline: Palin for President?
summary: A transcript of the weekend's program on FOX News Channel.
